title: Mourning the death of Charles H. Jennings, former Lodi Town Supervisor and longtime attorney
fulltext:
LEGISLATIVE RESOLUTION mourning the death of Charles H. Jennings, former
Lodi Town Supervisor and longtime attorney

WHEREAS,  It  is  the  custom of this Legislative Body to pay tribute to
citizens of the State of New York  whose  lifework  and  civic  endeavor
served to enhance the quality of life in their communities and the great
State of New York; and
  WHEREAS, Charles H. Jennings of Lodi, New York, died on Monday, Novem-
ber 1, 2010, at the age of 87; and
  WHEREAS,  Born  in Lodi on October 1, 1923, son of the late Charles L.
and Helen (Bainbridge) Jennings, Charles H. Jennings attended  the  Lodi
High School, and graduated from Ovid High School in 1942; and
  WHEREAS,  Charles  H. Jennings was drafted into the United States Army
in 1943, while attending Houghton College; he served his  country  as  a
Sergeant  with the 84th Infantry Division, and was severely wounded near
the end of World War II; subsequently, he was awarded a Purple Heart and
Bronze Star for his courage and valor; and
  WHEREAS, Following a lengthy recovery in England, Charles H.  Jennings
returned  to  Germany to work behind the lines before returning home and
continuing his education at Houghton; and
  WHEREAS, After graduating from Houghton in  1948,  with  a  degree  in
History,  Charles  H.  Jennings  earned  a  law degree from Northwestern
University in 1950, and opened a private law practice in Lodi; and
  WHEREAS, Under the Rockefeller Administration, he was appointed  Chief
of the Bureau of Surplus Real Property in Albany under the Department of
State in Albany and eventually Director of the Division of Land Utiliza-
tion under the Office of General Services; and
  WHEREAS,  Charles  H. Jennings distinguished himself in his profession
and by his  sincere  dedication  and  substantial  contribution  to  the
welfare of his community; and
  WHEREAS, Charles H. Jennings's commitment to excellence, and his spir-
it  of  humanity,  carried over into all fields of enterprise, including
charitable and civic endeavors; and
  WHEREAS, In 1957, Charles H. Jennings was elected Lodi  Town  Supervi-
sor;  in this capacity for several terms, among many accomplishments, he
helped save the West Lodi Cemetery from neglect and financial  distress;
he  had also been an active member of the Interlaken Reformed Church and
a participant of  the  Farmerville-Union  Lodge  of  Free  and  Accepted
Masons; and
  WHEREAS,  In 1961, Charles H. Jennings married Virginia Taylor and for
20 years, they maintained homes in  both  Slingerlands,  New  York,  and
Lodi, New York; and
  WHEREAS,  Upon  his  retirement  from  New  York  State,  the Jennings
returned full time to Lodi while Charles devoted his time to his private
practice; and
  WHEREAS, One of his greatest accomplishments was being instrumental in
the founding of the Lodi Historical Society and  serving  as  its  first
president; Lodi's red brick Methodist Church was in shambles, and it was
given to the fledgling society to prevent its destruction; and
  WHEREAS,  Charles  H. Jennings also helped with the restoration of the
1852 E. & G. G. Hook Tracker Organ; this valuable instrument lives on to
again and again delight audiences during performances thanks to the hard
work and determination of Charles and Virginia Jennings; and
  WHEREAS, Predeceased by his brother, Clayton, Charles H.  Jennings  is
survived  by his wife of 49 years, Virginia "Ginny" Jennings; his daugh-
ter, Amy (Craig) Pemberton; one  grandson,  Joseph  Craig  Pemberton;  a

sister,  Leona  Rosbaugh; and a brother, George (Lois) Jennings, as well
as several nieces and nephews; and
  WHEREAS,  Armed  with  a  humanistic  spirit,  imbued  with a sense of
compassion, and comforted by a loving family, Charles H. Jennings leaves
behind a legacy which will long endure the  passage  of  time  and  will
remain  as a comforting memory to all he served and befriended; a wealth
of knowledge and a wonderful resource for the Lodi community, his joyful
presence will be greatly missed; now, therefore, be it
  RESOLVED, That this Legislative Body pause  in  its  deliberations  to
mourn  the  death  of  Charles  H.  Jennings,  distinguished citizen and
devoted member of his community; and be it further
  RESOLVED, That a copy of this Resolution, suitably engrossed, be tran-
smitted to the family of Charles H. Jennings.
